newsitem.title: UK: NWE gasoline ends firm on Elf strike, arbitrage.
newsitem.headline: NWE gasoline ends firm on Elf strike, arbitrage.

text.p: NWE gasoline prices ended firm on Tuesday due to the twin props of the arbitrage to the U.S. and the strike by Elf refinery workers in France, traders said.
A 30,000 to 35,000 tonne Eurograde cargo was heard sold out of NWE to the U.S. for loading December 15-20, traders said, but this could not be confirmed.
Elf was also rumoured to be a small buyer of superplus and leaded material but this also was not confirmed.
Eurograde barges traded as high as $219 fob ARA, up $4, before ending the day at $216/$218, traders said. Rotterdam running refinery material ended at $220/$222.
Traders also awaited the weekly American Petroleum Institute report. U.S. traders expected gasoline inventories to rise by about 700,000 barrels.
Unions and managers at Elf agreed on Tuesday to concrete negotiations over pay and working conditions to try to resolve the six-day-old strike. Talks will start on Thursday.
"It's definitely underpinning the market," said one London trader.
The strike has crippled a quarter of French refinery capacity and the three refineries with combined capacity of 440,000 barrels per day make up three-quarters of Elf's European refining network.
Analysts said Elf produces about 100,000 bpd of gasoline and feeds 60,000 bpd of that to the French market, whose gasoline demand is about 350,000 bpd.
In Germany, demand is satisfied and has not been significantly hit by the French strikes, a barge trader there said.
"The consumer is well supplied and refineries are running full blast," he said.
